head.title: The Oops Girl With the Big Smile and the Little Voice

hedline.hl1: The Oops Girl With the Big Smile and the Little Voice

abstract.p: Jon Pareles reviews rock concert by Britney Spears at Jones Beach Theater; photos (M)

block.p: ''What you see is what you get,'' Britney Spears sang at the Jones Beach Theater on Tuesday night. And what you get from this 18-year-old singer is a big smile, a little voice, gushes of sincerity, hardworking dance routines, shameless advertising and a determination to play both sides of pubescence for all they're worth. To an audience full of squealing little girls, Ms. Spears previewed adolescent romance as a realm where all that matters are a girl's feelings and her wardrobe.

Ms. Spears, whose two albums have sold 16 million copies in the United States, makes Madonna seem like a tortured artist. She is eager to please and eager to sell both her music and her sponsors' products. Her face on advertising posters greeted concertgoers at the entrance; commercials were shown between sets. Since she is sponsored by both a camera company and dairy farmers, fans could have instant photos taken next to a Britney cutout with a milk mustache.

''What you see is what you get,'' Britney Spears sang at the Jones Beach Theater on Tuesday night. And what you get from this 18-year-old singer is a big smile, a little voice, gushes of sincerity, hardworking dance routines, shameless advertising and a determination to play both sides of pubescence for all they're worth. To an audience full of squealing little girls, Ms. Spears previewed adolescent romance as a realm where all that matters are a girl's feelings and her wardrobe.

Ms. Spears, whose two albums have sold 16 million copies in the United States, makes Madonna seem like a tortured artist. She is eager to please and eager to sell both her music and her sponsors' products. Her face on advertising posters greeted concertgoers at the entrance; commercials were shown between sets. Since she is sponsored by both a camera company and dairy farmers, fans could have instant photos taken next to a Britney cutout with a milk mustache.

But her hits, which reached a nation of young mall shoppers, were what brought the advertisers. Ms. Spears gets her best material from a Swedish pop consortium led by Max Martin. Their songs chug along in minor keys, pumped up with hard-rock guitar chords and punctuated by throaty little moans. The lyrics switch between promises of loyalty and pouty kiss-offs, growing marginally more assertive on Ms. Spears's second album, ''Oops! . . . I Did It Again'' (Jive).

The songs are often about being lonely or broken-hearted, wishing a lost love would come back. Yet her show keeps her surrounded with perky dancers who are as compliant as a high-school clique, following her moves and sometimes raising her aloft. Her voice, suitable for the lead in a road-show production of ''Annie,'' doesn't often stand on its own; it's carried by backup singers and, possibly, prerecorded harmonies. But she does make sure to moan.

As scripted by the Swedes, Ms. Spears's main complaint is that people keep telling her that her dresses are too short. Singing ''What U See (Is What U Get),'' which insists that she's faithful even if she likes to dress and dance seductively, she wore glittery jeans and a halter top and clutched the kind of silver pole that strippers use. When she reached the line, ''Take me as I am,'' she twitched her hips in a clear bump and grind. Throughout the show, she kept tearing away baggy clothes to wear navel-baring outfits underneath. But she plays the good girl, not the vamp. The boy who won a ''Meet Britney'' contest onstage got an arm's-length handshake and a polite ''Nice to meet you.'' With her long blond hair extensions, chesty figure and unfailing smile, Ms. Spears has often been compared to a Barbie doll. During a set that lasted slightly more than an hour, she went through enough costumes and scenarios for a Mattel showroom. She was a little girl in a bedroom full of teddy bears, a fairy tale princess, a sailor-suited U.S.O. entertainer, a hippie goddess, a Catholic-school cutup and a homecoming queen.

Her finale, of course, was ''Oops! . . . I Did It Again,'' about coyly leading on a would-be boyfriend. Phallic red inflatable columns reared all around her like avenging lip glosses. As she sang its last, taunting line -- ''I'm not that innocent'' -- she descended into a fiery pit, not to be seen again. Equating adult sexuality with hellfire, she doesn't mind as long as it heats up her career.

Teenypop shows always have a gaggle of opening acts with taped backups, and Ms. Spears brought along three warm-ups. No Authority, four young men in tough-guy black T-shirts, had unctuous love songs and half-hearted choreography; BBMak, who didn't dance, applied 1970's folk-rock strumming and high harmonies to protestations of love. Innosense, a five-woman group, put the moves of a cheerleading squad behind catchy, straightforward come-ons. The tour continues tonight at Jones Beach and at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on Sunday and Monday.
